physDesc.p: Five pages typewritten in black ink. Address given for H. D. in the top left corner of the first page: Mrs. Richard Aldington care of Sir John Ellerman 1 South Audley Street London W. 1, England. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: Thank you ever so much for your letter of January 1st, which came just as I was starting out on a lecture trip, so I have waited until now to answer it. Now I am going to have an operation this week, and I do not know when I shall be up to writing again.

It was awfully nice of you to be so interested in the Contemporary Club row. I was only annoyed with them because I had especially stipulated that there should be no discussion. I think that the time for discussing the new poetry has gone by. I am willing to talk about it, explain it, anything, but I will not stand up to be badgered even with the result, as always happens, of my beating my opponents. But at the Contemporary Club there was no possibility of discussion, since all they did was to call me names. I had used some of your work and some of Sandburg’s to illustrate my points, so you and Sandburg came in for a round robin of diatribes, and I personally was called every name you possibly can think of which was insulting. As there was no way of answering these gentlemen, except by saying "You’re another," I refused to answer at all, merely telling the Club that I had made this stipulation about there being no discussion, that it had been agreed to by their secretary, and that I did not think they were keeping faith with me. On the whole I think my silence scored as well as any eloquence would have done. But I realized after that meeting more than I had ever realized before how impossible it was for you to live in Philadelphia.

I am happy to say that Philadelphia is now in the last century, and that in other places there is a very different attitude. New York is most anxious to hear everything. I had 921 people to hear me read at St. Mark’s in-the-Bouwerie in November, and 720 at Columbia University a few days later, so you can see that there is an interest, and even those in the high places are taking things up. I am to give the Phi Beta Kappa poem at Columbia University in June, and what is still funnier, so funny that it causes me to smile, I am to receive the degree of Doctor of Literature from a Western University this Commencement. Oh, Hilda, but the world is a funny place!

I sold "The Islands" to the "North American Review," and it has already appeared, so I suppose you have the cheque by this time. "Thetis" is at the moment being considered by "The Bookman," and I certainly hope they will take it. When may we expect another book from you, my dear? Before long, I hope. But certainly I have been too ill to think of books. Winifred writes that she hopes you are going to Greece with her. I wonder if you do. Personally, I think that the charms of your baby will keep you where you are, and I imagine that travelling with Winifred is a bit strenuous. Soon an eager child must require a dragon of strength to keep up with her it seems to me. I do hope that she will come to America. I think that it will do her good and open her eyes, and I believe that she stands much more chance of getting an audience here than she does at home.

Of course I should be delighted to write the Preface to her book. I only did not say so in loud tones because I did not want to make her feel obliged to have me. She is such a queer child that I am always afraid of treading on her toes, and I did not want to seem to push myself in where she did not want me to be. It is unfortunate that her knowledge of business is so slight for instead of giving Macmillan’s letter to me to Constable and letting them decide what they would do, and then letting me decide what I would do about the Preface, she returned the letter to me, which means that the whole transaction is to do over again, and now she tells me that Constable is printing her book over there, which changes the proposition entirely. However, I saw Mr. Marsh when I was in New York, and he says that he thinks they will be perfectly willing to take sheets on condition that I write the Preface for the book, so I have sent the letter back to Winifred and told her this, and possibly something will happen now.

You asked me what I thought of your little friend Viola Jordan. She was a little fresh, but rather pleasantly so, and she was so genuinely enthusiastic that I enjoyed seeing her. Her husband is a very nice fellow; he seemed very quiet and dependable. She is what the French call une fausse naïve. She poses as if she were very simple and innocent, but I think myself that she is far more developed mentally and far shrewder than she would give the impression of being. I do not personally care for poses and should have preferred her to be natural, but, nevertheless, I enjoyed them both. They have been playing with the Greenwich Village crowd a good deal, and she has got rather tired of it, as, indeed, has every one else. It amuses me to observe as we go on how those of us who are sincere and whose work is a part of ourselves, our very flesh and blood, rise to the top, while those who wrote with the surface or shell go gradually under.

The "Little Review" has got queerer and queerer until now it is really almost crazy, and nobody has any respect for it at all. I never think of writing for it, and I think nobody else of any standing does. The "Dial" has been sold to a young Harvard man named Schofield Thayer and they are trying to make it into a sort of "Seven Arts." Only one number of the revised magazine has appeared as yet. They have turned it into a monthly and may do something with it, but I have my doubts, as I think their probably object is to make an organ in which the recently graduated Harvard man can air his views and his work, and there do not seem to be any such of any great talent at present. They have not asked me to contribute which I take is a sign that they are keeping it more or less in a ring. I wanted to go to see them when I was in New York, but did not have the time. They have every reason to succeed. The owner is a rich man, and this is his hobby, but I doubt whether they do.

Harriet’s magazine goes along in its own way. It has its own clientele, but it has no influence whatever outside of a small group. It is exceedingly funny to me that a woman could have had a magazine running for six years and never increase its circulation to any amount that counts as a circulation and have no influence on the growth of poetry in any way. It would horrify her if she knew this was the case, but it is, and it is surprising and shows Harriet’s glorious ineptness better than anything else could possibly do. Poetry is a power over here. People are avid for it. Poets have no difficulty in getting published. The public is large; the editors eager. And to conduct a poetry magazine which has not counted at all is really a bit singular.

My own books are selling more all the time, which pleases me, and even the poor, dear, old Imagist Anthologies, which we are letting go out of print, still have a sale for their remainder as you will see by the enclosed money order. The sale is not brilliant, but it still shows a demand, although not enough to keep the books in print.

Do write to me again and cheer up my convalescence and tell me all your plans. Do let me know whether or not you did go with Winifred or where you are. Richard wrote me that you were with the Ellermans so I am sending this letter here.
body.closer: Ada joins me in much love, Affectionately yours,
